Award.AwardTitle: Propagation of localized compaction in brittle granular materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336952
PI: Valdes

Granular packs (soils, sedimentary rocks, industrial powders, crowded bacteria, pills, foodstuffs) typically exhibit localized deformations during loading: severe relative displacements amongst grains occur within localization zones, whereas minimal deformations are suffered by the rest of the material. Localization varies with type of loading (e.g., shear vs. compaction), packing characteristics (e.g., porosity), and grain characteristics (e.g., sizes, shape, roughness, internal porosity). This project centers on localized compaction, i.e., porosity loss in the localization zone, and focuses specifically on elucidating a recently discovered phenomenon: the periodic propagation of localized compaction in granular packs composed of porous grains. Laboratory experiments that involve load-deformation and granular breakage measurements, acoustic emission and wave velocity monitoring, and video capture for digital image correlation analyses are implemented to understand why and how such phenomenon takes place. This understanding is attained by characterization of the propagation process (i.e., speed, spatial extent, periodicity) and identification of the range of conditions required for its manifestation, placing emphasis on the role that material properties (e.g., grain crushability), loading conditions (e.g., imposed deformation rate), and boundary conditions (e.g., near vs. far) play on the characteristics of the deformation response.

This work will lead to an increased understanding of localization mechanics and nonlocal effects in granular materials. In turn, this understanding shall serve in furthering the development of characterization and prediction tools for processes wherein localization takes place, including soil and rock engineering (e.g., fault gauging, slope instability, in-site soil testing), and geo-mechanics (e.g., hydrocarbon production and reservoir damage) processes, natural and industrial granular flows, snow avalanches, and deformation of non-granular porous solids, such as engineered cellular foams and composites. This project supports undergraduate and graduate research students, furthers collaboration between a Hispanic-serving institution (San Diego State University) and an international research university (University of Sydney), and contributes to the Nation?s commitment to entice middle- and high school students towards the study of science and engineering, through the development of research-related didactic tools coupled with teacher-training implemented within the nationwide program Project-Lead-the-Way.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a first-of-a-kind study to identify, understand, and describe the response of ‘crunchy’ materials (i.e., brittle porous media) to forced compression. ‘Crunchy materials are (1) brittle (suffer little deformation before breaking), and (2) highly porous (are composed primarily of pores). Ceramic foams, cereal grain packs, and snow are salient examples. Before our investigation, there was little to no information regarding the compaction response of such materials, especially with respect to variations in compaction velocity.

The major outcome achieved with this award is described as follows. We conducted experiments where, for each, we filled a transparent tube with a pack of puffed cereal grains and compressed the pack with a piston at a velocity V. We conducted tests with different V’s. For each test, we measured the pack’s resistance during compression, filmed the compressing pack, and used the video to extract local deformation measurements throughout the pack during compression. At medium V, we found that the material compacted in an oscillatory pattern, where a horizontal compaction band –separating compacting and non-compacting material– propagates periodically within the pack, during compression. We then developed and used a lattice model (like a network or grid) composed of breakable springs that connect masses, and found that not only did our model reproduce the medium-V experiment; it also produced highly dissimilar and non-oscillatory compaction patterns for low and high V. We then proceeded to conduct the low and high V experiments and confirmed the discovery attained by the model: an erratic pattern with uncorrelated compaction events at low V, and a diffuse pattern with homogeneous compaction at high V (see Figure 1). Stimulated by such results, we then used the model to predict results of experiments performed with snow (conducted by others who mimicked our initial experiment). The model worked, confirming (1) the applicability of the model, and (2) that snow and cereal belong in the same material category: crunchy matter. We then grouped the model parameters into dimensionless parameters, which we then varied in consequent simulations. These allowed us to produce a phase diagram (Figure 2) for crunchy media, which ultimately fulfills the main intent of this award: to capture the physics that give rise to compaction patterns that [may] arise. Importantly, this finding has broader impacts in that the phase diagram can be used to predict compaction patterns in crunchy media with knowledge of material and system parameters. This study was published in one of the most prestigious physics journals in the world: Nature Physics.

 

Additional studies funded through the award emerged from the work described above. (1) With the use of additional experiments, we developed an experimental technique to estimate the threshold velocity that separates the low-V erratic pattern and the medium-V oscillatory pattern, for a given material. The technique involves conducting relaxation tests on small packs (relaxation is the loss in resistance, i.e., stress, caused by a sudden halt of the piston; V = 0). (2) Additional experiments have enabled us to discover that a loaded crunchy medium rebounds in discrete jerks (i.e., not homogeneously), when unloaded. (3) Via experiments and model simulations with variable V, we discovered that strain-rate softening (essentially a loss in resistance with increasing V) is not necessary for unstable compaction patterns to emerge. This finding challenges currently-used modeling schemes that require the imposition of strain-rate softening laws to produce localization patterns in metallic alloys and stick-slip motion in crustal faults.
